qas.question: What schools do not offer free education?

context: In <a0_0>2012<a0_0/>, <b4_0>the modern use of <b5_0>electronic educational technology<b5_0/> (also called e-learning) had grown at 14 times the rate<b4_0/> of traditional learning.[clarification needed] <a1_0><b6_0>Open education<b6_0/><a1_0/> is fast growing to become the dominant form of education, for many reasons such as its efficiency and results compared to traditional methods. <a2_0>Cost of education<a2_0/> has been an issue throughout history, and a major political issue in most countries today. <a3_0>Online courses<a3_0/> often can be more expensive than face-to-face classes. Out of 182 colleges surveyed in 2009 <b7_0>nearly half said tuition for online courses was higher than for campus based ones<b7_0/>. Many large university institutions are now starting to offer free or almost free full courses such as Harvard, MIT and Berkeley teaming up to form edX. Other universities offering open education are <b8_0>Stanford, Princeton, Duke, Johns Hopkins, Edinburgh<b8_0/>, U. Penn, U. Michigan, U. Virginia, U. Washington, and Caltech. It has been called the biggest change in the way we learn since the printing press. Despite favorable studies on effectiveness, many people may still desire to choose traditional campus education for social and cultural reasons.
